Species: Bufo spinosus x Bufo bufo hybrid?
TSD_note: High mortality at both low (10) and high (25 degrees Celsius) temperature. Species identity is uncertain (see Nemeshazi & Bokony 2022 https://doi.org/10.1002/bies.202200039).
Other_note: Species identity is uncertain: published as Bufo vulgaris, but recently hypothesised that B. spinosus and B. bufo hybrids could be used (see Nemesházi & Bokony 2022 https://doi.org/10.1002/bies.202200039).

Data from those triploid and tetraploid hybrids were considered here for which sex ratio data were available at all three studied temperature ranges. 19-21 degrees Celsius caused either no strong sex-ratio bias or male excess, and 26-27 degrees Celsius caused either no strong sex-ratio bias or female excess.

Low temperatures were not tested.

No male-to-female sex reversal occured at 15 degrees Celsius in Rana dybowskii (Xu et al. (2022)  https://doi.org/10.1111/1749-4877.12577). We assessed TSD pattern based on individuals that were not fathered by pseudomale.
Threshold may be lower but sample sizes are too small.
High mortality at both low (10 degrees Celsius) and high (25 degrees Celsius) temperature in Piquet's study. The temperatures sometimes dropped below 10 degrees Celsius!
Other_note: supernumerary (B) chromosomes occur (Green & Sessions 1991 Amphibian Cytogenetics and Evolution: page 335)

TSD_note: Mortality rate also increased with temperature elevation, and at 30 degrees Celsius mortality was 100%.

The lowest temperature tested by Sakata et al (2005) was 16 degrees Celsius. Female-to-male sex reversal by high temperatures was suggested based on sex ratios by Uchida 1937, as cited by Chardard et al. (2004) Thermal sex reversals in amphibians. In: Temperature-dependent sex determination in vertebrates. Pages 59-67.
The most female-biased larval sex ratio was found in the warmest of seven ponds: 25 females and 13 males (marginally non-significant sex-ratio bias), the authors concluded no temperature-dependence.
